labels.title: The First Ministry under Responsible Government in New South Wales
labels.subtitle: Freeman Brothers

text.content: albumen silver photograph\n\nPurchased with funds provided by L Gordon Darling AC CMG 2009

Responsible government â€“ the system wherein members of the Executive (the premier and cabinet) are also elected members of Parliament â€“ was introduced in New South Wales in 1856. Prior to this, the colony had been administered by governors who, from 1824, governed with the assistance of a Legislative Council. The end of convict transportation, the gold rush, and other economic and social developments of the 1840s and 1850s contributed to demands for a more democratic system of government. A committee chaired by William Charles Wentworth (1790â€“1872) drew up a new constitution which was assented to by the British government in 1855. The first elections for the Legislative Assembly were held in March and April 1856, with the new Parliament meeting for the first time in May. The first ministry was sworn in in June 1856, its members being (left to right): Thomas Holt (1811â€“1888), treasurer; Sir William Manning (1811â€“1895), attorney-general; Sir Stuart Donaldson (1812â€“1867), premier; Sir John Darvall (1809â€“1883), solicitor-general; and George Robert Nichols (1809â€“1857), auditor-general and secretary for works.

labels.title: Henry Chamberlain Russell and family at Sydney Observatory
labels.subtitle: Charles Bayliss

text.content: albumen silver photograph\n\nCollection: National Portrait Gallery Gift of Joanna Russell Maher (nÃ©e Windeyer) 2018

Henry Chamberlain Russell CMG (1836â€“1907) (third from left), was one of nineteenth-century Sydneyâ€™s leading men of science. He started work at the Sydney Observatory after completing a degree at the University of Sydney in 1859 and by 1870 he was government astronomer. Extraordinarily active in his field, he photographed astronomical events, designed instruments for the Observatory, increased the number of weather stations and observers, and developed an international network of scientific contacts. From early 1877 he released a daily weather map; this may or may not have been the cause of an assassination attempt on him that year. A pioneer of limnology (the study of inland waters) and a keen natural historian, Russell remeasured existing calculations and found 500 new double stars; published numerous texts; helped establish technical education in New South Wales; and was the first University of Sydney graduate to be elected to the Royal Society. He also served as the universityâ€™s vice chancellor. His daughter, Jane Foss Russell (1863â€“1937) (right), was the second woman to gain a masterâ€™s degree from the University of Sydney, the only woman on its teaching staff in the 1890s, and a founder of the Womenâ€™s College.
gelatin silver photograph on paper\n\nGift of Ron Wylie 2007

Shigeo Sawada (1890-1940), trading company executive, came to Sydney in 1915 on behalf of Okura and Co Trading Ltd, the first independent Japanese company to establish a branch abroad. At that time, there was widespread suspicion that German firms were buying wool under cover of Japanese trading names, and one of Sawadaâ€™s early responsibilities was to reassure wool brokers that the Japanese market was above-board. Okura and Co built up extensive interests in Australian wool, barley, wheat, flour, hides and pelts in the interwar years, when Japan was one of Australiaâ€™s key trade partners; there were sixty or more trading companies in Sydney before World War II, with Japan, China and India purchasing 21% of Australia and New Zealandâ€™s clip in 1934-1935. Having settled in Mosman soon after his arrival, in 1920 Sawada moved into a guest house owned by the family of Nelson Illingworth, a prominent Sydney sculptor, who made the statuette of Henry Parkes in the collection of the National Portrait Gallery. In 1924 he married Illingworthâ€™s daughter, Thelma; the couple adopted a local urchin, Ron Wylie, in the 1930s. Conspicuous on the Sydney social circuit, Shigeo and Thelma Sawada lived in a house called Hakone in Mosman until Shigeoâ€™s death in 1940, by which time he had been Managing Director of Okura Co for three years. Shigeoâ€™s brother, Renzo Sawada, was Japanese ambassador to France, and later Ambassador Extraordinary and Plenipotentiary, Permanent Observer of Japan to the UN; Renzo presented the Peace Bell that stands at UN headquarters in New York. Shigeo Sawadaâ€™s ashes are divided between Japan and Mosman.
gelatin silver photograph on paper\n\nPurchased with funds provided by The Ian Potter Foundation 2007

Sir Sidney Kidman, pastoralist (1857â€“1935), was Australiaâ€™s â€˜cattle kingâ€™. Kidman ran away from his Adelaide home as a boy and worked as a cattleman, rouseabout and stockman and bullocky before establishing a butcherâ€™s shop in Cobar in the 1870s. This venture was successful enough for him to set up as a large squatter. In 1886 he bought his first station, in the Northern Territory; over the following twelve years he built up two giant chains of properties stretching across Queensland, New South Wales, South Australia and the Northern Territory. By the First World War he held land almost equal in area to that of Victoria. Arthur Triggs (1868â€“1936), pastoralist and collector, is sometimes referred to as the â€˜Kidman of the wool industryâ€™. Triggs came to Australia aged 19 and worked as an accountant in Yass before buying his first 8 000 wethers. From 1897 on he bought and leased properties studded along lines from Bourke to Kiandra, establishing a pattern of running between 250 000 and 500 000 sheep and some cattle at any one time. Triggs travelled often to London, where he indulged his passion for old books, manuscripts, coins and pictures, while his second wife, Mary, bought up specimens of antique lace. It became a truism that when Triggs prospered, so did Yass. After he died, a distinctive gateway, funded by public subscription, was erected in his honour in the townâ€™s Victoria Park.

audio.title: Sidney Kidman
audio.transcript:
I see George Philips started on the 11th with 520 fats, and that they are an extra good lot. I see you say there are in them 200 prime fat bullocks. Yes, he is a great old skite. I am glad you got them off, but I wish youâ€™d been able to send them by Pat Kennedy or someone who could handle them well, as the road is in a deplorable state from Birdsville to Hergett.

I got quite a shock to see you say there are 15000 cattle â€“ I thought there were about 9000.

I note what you say about going away at the end of the year. You are quite welcome to this leave. Iâ€™m very sorry indeed to hear you have anything the matter with you, because I must say youâ€™ve been more than satisfactory and the place has been managed cheaply, and well, by you, and Iâ€™m obliged for what you have done, and I will arrange to give you a bonus. At any rate, at the end of the year I will give you 100 pounds, and pay your wages for three months until we know if youâ€™ll be able to come back again. I would like to be fair to a man who has served me well. I hope youâ€™ll be able to come back for a year or two, or perhaps I could give you a place more inside somewhere.

I am pleased to have word from you and to see all you say. Thereâ€™s been some mistake, partly through my fault, and Monkira is under offer. I expect people will be coming out there to look at it but do not give them too good an account of the place as I do not want to sell it. Tell them that there are 750 bullocks there that are sold but have not been moved because of the bad season and if necessary, you can give a few of them a shoot down on the Bluff. I am leaving it in your hands to do what you think best, but you will understand that I do not want to sell and I hope they will turn it down.

Can you let me know something about the horses?
audio.acknowledgements: Kidman, Sidney (1925) Letter to Mr B.D Edwards, Monkira Station via Winton, 2 July 1925, _Letters from Sidney Kidman to Peirce Edwards: October 1938-1949_. Edwards, L., Toowoomba Queensland, Bib ID 2620110 National Library of Australia

labels.title: The first Australian first-class cricket team to tour England and North America
labels.subtitle: A & G Taylor

text.content: albumen photograph on carte de visite\n\nCollection: National Portrait Gallery Purchased 2013

The â€˜first Australian first-class cricket team to tour England and North Americaâ€™ was in fact the second Australian cricket side to contest matches internationally (a team of Indigenous players having done so in 1868), but is considered the first official national representative team to tour overseas. The team was led by Wollongong-born David Gregory (1845â€“1919), who had captained a combined New South Wales and Victoria team in its defeat of a touring English side in March 1877. Afterwards, in partnership with a Victorian named John Conway (1842â€“1909), Gregory put together a side to play a series of matches in England. Recruited were New South Welshmen Frederick Spofforth (1853â€“1926), William (Billy) Murdoch (1854â€“1911), Thomas Garrett (1858â€“1943), Charles Bannerman (1851â€“1930) and his brother Alec (1854â€“1924); Victorians Francis (Frank) Allan (1849â€“1917), Thomas Horan (1854â€“1916), John McCarthy (Jack) Blackham (1854â€“1932) and Henry Boyle (1847â€“1907); and a Tasmanian, George Bailey (1853â€“1926). Another player, Billy Midwinter (1851â€“1890), joined the team in England but defected halfway through the tour to play for Gloucestershire. The players and their two managers (Conway and William Gibbes) contributed Â£50 each to finance the tour, playing a number of warm-up matches against local teams before leaving for England in March 1878. They defeated a Marylebone Cricket Club eleven (captained by WG Grace) by nine wickets at Lordâ€™s in May 1878, bowling them out for 33 and 19, with Australian fast bowler Spofforth â€“ aka â€˜The Demonâ€™ â€“ taking six wickets for four runs in the first innings and four for sixteen in the second. Then, between June and September, the team played games against Middlesex, Surrey and Gloucestershire (Spofforth again being the main destroyer); and en route home stopped in America for fixtures in Philadelphia and San Francisco. A crowd of 20,000 people is said to have welcomed them back to Sydney at the conclusion of the tour, which had proved an enormous financial as well as sporting success. Spofforth, Murdoch, Horan, Garrett, Blackham and Alec Bannerman all featured in the Australian outfit whose defeat of England at The Oval in August 1882 initiated â€˜The Ashesâ€™ test series â€“ which remains international cricketâ€™s most storied rivalry.\n\nPhotographers Andrew and George Taylor opened their first studio in east London in 1866 and by the early 1880s had expanded their operations throughout the city and to branches in many regional areas. Like many studios of the period, A & G Taylor specialised in cartes de visite, the format typically employed for souvenir-style portraits of notables and celebrities. In the back row, left to right, are: John Conway, George Bailey, William Gibbes, and Frank Allan; seated in the middle row, left to right, are: Jack Blackham, Billy Murdoch, Tom Horan, David Gregory, Alec Bannerman and Fred Spofforth; and seated at the front, left to right, are Tom Garrett, Charles Bannerman and Henry Boyle.
carte de visite photograph\n\nCollection: National Portrait Gallery Purchased 2018

labels.title: Master Johnny Day, Australian Champion Pedestrian
labels.subtitle: Unknown artist

text.content: albumen photograph carte de visite\n\nPurchased 2014

'The Australian Wonder', Johnny Day (1856â€“1885), was an undefeated world-champion juvenile walker. Born in Victoria, he competed in Australia and London, winning an incredible 101 walking matches by age ten. The activity of competitive walking, or 'Pedestrianism' as it was known, attracted large crowds at its peak in the mid-nineteenth century. The sport's early history dates back to 1600 when the English aristocracy would send their footmen ahead of their carriages to deliver messages. To the amusement of the nobility, the footmen were often pitched against one another in races upon which large sums of money were wagered. By 1800, competitive long-distance walking had emerged as a popular sport and by mid-century it had become glamorised as a lucrative international sport. In late 1863 the Argus reported that 'Martin, of Bendigo, a pedestrian of some note, has challenged John Day, of Ballarat, a lad eight years of age, to walk him a distance of 800 yards for Â£5 a side'. In 1865 the 'Kentish Dwarf' and Master Johnny Day had a trial of speed on the Ballarat Cricket Ground. In 1867 Day was said to have walked 300 times around 'the circle' at the New Royal Victoria Theatre in Sydney in an attempt to cover five miles in less than 50 minutes. Towards the end of the 1860s, Day turned from pedestrianism to equestrianism and his name began appearing in the columns of horseracing pundits. In 1870, at fourteen years of age, Day jockeyed the bay gelding Nimblefoot to victory in the Melbourne Cup in what was one of the most controversial finishes in Cup history. Young jockey Day got the last 'ounce of his mount', pipping the British thoroughbred Lapdog at the post and withal recording the quickest race time in the first ten years of the Melbourne Cup with three minutes, 37 seconds. By the turn of the century pedestrianism had been largely superseded by competitive cycling. Johnny Day didn't live long enough to witness it, being only 28 when he died of Addison's disease in June 1885.

direct positive colour photograph on paper

Gift of the artists 2003

Â© Montalbetti & Campbell

Cathy Freeman OAM (b. 1973) was eight years old when she won her first race at a school athletics carnival in north Queensland. Aged sixteen, she was selected for the Australian womenâ€™s 4 x 100m relay team that took out the gold medal at the Commonwealth Games in Auckland, making her the first Aboriginal athlete to win a Commonwealth gold medal. She won two more gold medals at the Commonwealth Games in Canada in 1994. The first Aboriginal track and field athlete to represent Australia at the Olympic Games, she won a silver medal in Atlanta in 1996. She was ranked first in the world in her signature event, the 400m, in which she won back-to-back World Championships in 1997 and 1999, and, memorably, the Olympic gold medal in front of her home crowd in Sydney in 2000. The Catherine (now Cathy) Freeman Foundation was established in 2007 to enhance educational opportunities for Aboriginal children.\n\nThis photograph was taken at the NSW Academy of Sport in December 1994. As Denis Montalbetti and Gay Campbell noted: 'It's irrelevant how many times a person has been photographed. Our aim is to create unique images of them, to be part of their testimony â€¦ a part of their photographic history.'

audio.title: Cathy Freeman audio description
audio.transcript:
A photographic portrait of Cathy Freeman created by Montalbetti+Campbell in 1995.

The photograph shows only the face of Cathy and at 121.0 cm x 90.0 cm is roughly four times larger than life. Coloured in tones ranging from sepia to velvety black, her face is closely cropped to exclude her hair and much of her forehead.

Her strong, black, gently arched brows span the width of the image and a water droplet rests in the slight crease between them. Deeply set almond shaped eyes gaze directly forward with intense focus that commands attention. There are dark shadows in the inner corners of her eyes that extend underneath them and a short way down her nose. Cathyâ€™s nose is narrow at the bridge but broadens towards the tip and another water droplet pools at the side of her left nostril.  
Light shines on her left cheek making it lighter than her right. Her cheeks are slightly lifted. On the right side, the area between her nose and upper lip is in shadow.  
Her full lips are framed by subtle creases on either side. She holds her mouth closed, a droplet gleams and drips from under her rounded chin, suspended in an extended tear shape. Behind it, a narrow band of her neck is visible, the rest disappearing into deep black. 

**Audio description written by Krysia Kitch and voiced by Emma Bedford**

text.content:
type C photograph on paper

Gift of the artist 2010

Â© George Fetting/Copyright Agency, 2023

Oodgeroo Noonuccal (1920â€“1993) was a Quandamooka woman, activist, poet, writer and educator. Born in Minjerribah (North Stradbroke Island), she became Queensland State Secretary of the Federal Council for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Advancement in 1961, and campaigned successfully for amendments to Sections 51(xxvi) and 127 of the Constitution in 1967. Throughout her life, she aimed to promote cultural pride among Aboriginal people through her writing, which she described as 'sloganistic, civil rightish, plain and simple'. Her first book of poetry, _We are Going_, was published in 1964. Noonuccal returned to Minjerribah in 1971 where she taught Aboriginal culture to thousands of school children, and published two children's books. Having gained world acclaim for her writing and advocacy (for which she was also conferred with four honorary doctorates), she published her last collection of poems, _Kath Walker in China_, in 1988. That year, she reassumed her tribal name in protest at the Bicentennial celebrations, and returned the MBE she had been awarded in 1970.\n\nAlthough Noonuccal had a reputation for fierceness, George Fetting invited her to be included in his exhibition of prominent Australian women, and found her very welcoming. He photographed her at her modest home on Minjerribah; this singular and searching image is the lasting legacy of his visit.

audio.title: Kath Walker part two
audio.transcript:
In 1965 I think it was, we were invited to go in and talk to the then prime minister, Sir Robert Menzies. There was a deputation from all over Australia of Aboriginal spokesmen and women and we did go in. Sir Robert Menzies had told the public and the politicians, the people of the House, that he would not have a referendum in his lifetime as prime minister. Heâ€™d been badly beaten on the referendum before where he had appealed to the people to outlaw Communism and when the people said â€˜No outlawing of the Communist Partyâ€™, Sir Robert Menzies refused then to have anything to do with referendums in his lifetime as prime minister.

We lobbied the House of Parliament and itâ€™s to their discredit, really, that when we asked them to bring out the laws concerning the Aboriginal people that there was no laws, no books on the Aboriginal people in their archives or libraries, and they had to quickly have them printed, so that the politicians could read what it was, for and against the Aborigines. There was one, however, on the national â€“ the Canberra law book saying that if Aboriginals go into Canberra, any Justice of the Peace could declare them illegal immigrants into Canberra and they could be chased out of Canberra. This still applied to us, incidentally, at this period of time. And we always made a joke of it when we went to Canberra, you know, â€˜If you get into trouble, you know the law on the book. If a JP says Get Out, make sure you get your blanket,â€™ because the law still said that before sending them out of Canberra, they must first issue them with one government blanket. So we were determined weâ€™d get our government blanket if ever they threw us out.  
We told everyone this and we made it a laughingstock â€“ Canberra a laughingstock â€“ to such an extent that the first thing Sir Robert Menzies did was delete that off the Canberra constitution. So itâ€™s no longer there.
audio.acknowledgements: This oral history of Kath Walker is from the De Berg Collection in the National Library of Australia. For more information, or to hear full versions of the recordings, visit the National Library of Australia website.

audio.title: Kath Walker part one
audio.transcript:
I would say that the majority of the Australian people voted Yes in favour of the Aboriginal people merely to clear their guilty conscience. Itâ€™s easy to put a mark on a ballot paper, and I must say this definitely, that there was a small minority group of sincere Australian people but I would say 75 [per cent] of those who voted Yes did it to clear their guilty conscience.

Incidentally, itâ€™s interesting to understand why those terrible discriminative laws were put into the books. In the first place, our civic fathers, or the white manâ€™s civic fathers of long ago, during the â€˜soothing of the dying pillowâ€™ era, the politicians, or the statesmen of that time, were writing over to Queen Victoria saying, â€˜The Aborigine is dying out.â€™ And true, he was â€“ they were poisoning him with strychnine in the waterholes and they were shooting him, and they were doing all sorts of things. And the Aborigine dropped from 300,000 strong to 80,000 in a very short period of time. So it was quite natural for them to say the Aborigine was a dying race.

Now it was during this period of time that the Constitution was being fixed, and as they thought we were a dying race, to save themselves a lot of bother they said, â€˜Well we will not count the Aborigines and we do not have to make laws for the Aborigines, because theyâ€™re going to die out anywayâ€™. And this is the reason today why Aboriginals have not had any education, any decent housing, any facilities that the white Australian enjoys today. Itâ€™s because of that stupid business of thinking the Aboriginals were going to die out.

Mind you, the Aboriginals are a determined lot, and theyâ€™re quite ungrateful. They didnâ€™t die, they lived on and are still living on; in spite of the many attempts to commit genocide and assassinate us all, we are still here. I think weâ€™ll last the white man out, truly.
audio.acknowledgements: This oral history of Kath Walker is from the De Berg Collection in the National Library of Australia. For more information, or to hear full versions of the recordings, visit the National Library of Australia website.

audio.title: Oodgeroo Noonuccal audio description
audio.transcript:
George Fettingâ€™s large photographic portrait of writer and activist Oodgeroo of the Noonuccal Tribe was taken in 1992 and printed in 2009. It is 110 centimetres high by 88.2 centimetres wide in a modest fine wooden frame.

This large photograph is a close-up of Oodgerooâ€™s face resting in her left hand, which frames the lower part of her face. Chin resting on thumb and fingers pointing up towards her eyes and placed along her cheek bone. Her face is slightly to the right of centre. Soft light illuminates the right side of her face with the extreme left of her forehead, nose, and hand cast into shadow. The sepia tones of her skin stand out against a black background.

Oodgerooâ€™s face is cropped across her high wrinkled forehead, and short silvered hair is glimpsed on either side. Between her brows is a single deep vertical furrow. She has large dark eyes with bags beneath them. She gazes to her left at the camera. Her nose is straight and deep creases run from each side of her nose to her closed lips and then continue downward to the edge of her face. A faint line shows the edges of a dark shirt that disappears into the background. 

The elements of a slightly raised left eyebrow, her liquid eyes, the pores of her skin and the whirls and cracks of her fingerprints create a detailed textural portrait of this Quandamooka woman.

**Audio description script written by Krysia Kitch and voiced by Kate Matthews**

text.content:
triptych of type C photographs on on paper

Commissioned with funds from the Farrell Family Foundation and the Basil Bressler Bequest 2002

Â© Bill Henson

Simone Young AM (b. 1961) is one of the leading conductors of her generation. At 25, she became the youngest resident conductor at Opera Australia, and was the first woman to conduct at the Vienna State Opera and at the Bastille Opera in Paris. Director of Opera Australia from 2001 to 2003, she then worked for ten years, from 2005, as the Artistic Director of the Hamburg State Opera and Music Director of the Hamburg Philharmonic Orchestra. Based in Sussex, England, Young is returning to Australia in 2022 to become the Sydney Symphony Orchestra's chief conductor. \n\nBill Henson and Young share a love of German Romantic opera, and this connection constituted the foundation of the relationship between sitter and artist. Henson says of the portrait: 'I was interested in the way great music affects us. The sheer force of such beauty causes us to fall in love. It is that love that I wanted to see transform the subjectâ€™s appearance. But strangely, to suggest any of this, one must step back â€¦ Only across such a distance might one describe such intimacy and such longing.' Young herself has compared the portrait's structure to the three acts of an opera.

audio.title: Bill Henson
audio.transcript:
I didnâ€™t want to make pictures which were just a document of something else. I wanted to make pictures which were a thing in their own right. And so, by photographing her in the pit with an orchestra rehearsing, I just thought this [is] just never going to look as interesting as in its own right. So the picture becomes the subject rather than, you know, the event thatâ€™s being documented being the subject. This is one of those great conundrums for photographers. I organised for Simone to visit me in my studio. We had a conversation, I said â€˜Well look, what are you working on at the moment?â€™ She was preparing to conduct the _Rosenkavalier,_ the Richard Strauss. And I said, â€˜Oh well, you know, why donâ€™t we put it on and why donâ€™t you conduct to the music?â€™ I said, â€˜You know, itâ€™s strange, of course.â€™ And she said, â€˜Itâ€™s very strange, because I lead, whereas if I listen to a recording and try to conduct, Iâ€™m following the recording.â€™ And I said, â€˜Well it might be interesting for you, letâ€™s give it a go.â€™ And she said, â€˜Well, you know, the only recording that I really have been listening to carefully is by Erich Kleiber, and, you know, youâ€™re not going to have that.â€™ And I go, â€˜Well here it is.â€™

She got into it, and she started conducting and I was just taking pictures and we kept going and we kept going and we both got quite a good sweat up. In fact in the end we â€“ she conducted the whole opera. Like, we were having a lot of fun. She was like, going off and I just kept shooting it and shooting it and shooting it and at the end of it like a normal session that I would do with one of my models, it was like both people are kind of exhausted and perspiring. And she packed up and caught a cab and I went back to the lab and started working on the pictures.

You know, there are lots of things that are interesting and theyâ€™re technically fine but youâ€™re looking for that sort of special thing in a shoot, and so over the process of weeks, or months or years in some cases you narrow it down to those few images that you think are essential or that capture something, that are somehow compelling. And yeah, [I] narrowed it down to three. I couldnâ€™t get it down to one. Thatâ€™s how the process worked.
audio.acknowledgements: This recording was made during interviews for the National Portrait Gallery's [_Portrait Stories_][1] series.\n\n [1]: /stories

text.content:
single channel moving image, colour, sound, 2 minutes, 47 seconds

Purchased 2011

Â© Merilyn Fairskye/Copyright Agency, 2023

Sir William Deane AC KBE KC (b. 1931), High Court judge, was Governor-General of Australia from 1996 to 2001. Spending his primary school years in Canberra, Deane was educated in Catholic schools and the University of Sydney. He returned to the ACT to work in the Attorney-Generalâ€™s Department before undertaking postgraduate study in international law in The Hague. Called to the Bar in 1957, he lectured for five years at Sydney University before being appointed Kingâ€™s Counsel in 1966 (at the time named Queen's Counsel). Eleven years later he was appointed a judge in the Equity Division of the Supreme Court of New South Wales, a judge of the Federal Court of Australia and the President of the Australian Trade Practices Tribunal. In July 1982, he was appointed a Justice of the High Court of Australia, on which he served until he retired in late 1995 to take up his appointment as Governor-General. Sworn in by Paul Keating and farewelled by John Howard, Deane is popularly renowned as a champion of the common person, and Indigenous Australians in particular. â€˜The ultimate test of our worth as a nation will be how we treat our most vulnerableâ€™, he said on his last day in office, when he hosted a lunch for homeless children at Government House and expressed regret that Indigenous and non-Indigenous Australians had not yet formally reconciled. Deane stayed in Canberra after retirement and is now Patron of the Canberra Centenary celebrations.
single channel moving image, colour, sound, 2 minutes, 50 seconds\n\nPurchased 2011
1/6 plate daguerreotype, hand coloured with case\n\nGift of Fiona Turner (nÃ©e Robertson) and John Robertson 2011. Donated through the Australian Government's Cultural Gifts Program.

William Robertson (1798â€“1874), pastoralist and entrepreneur, was born in a village south of Inverness, Scotland, one of the eight children of farmer Donald Robertson and his wife Christina. With his brother, John, he emigrated to Van Diemenâ€™s Land in 1822. They took up a 1400 acre land grant before establishing a business with their younger brothers, James and Daniel, on Elizabeth Street, Hobart, in 1832. In September 1834, he married Margaret Whyte (1811â€“1866), the daughter of free settlers George and Jessie Whyte, who had emigrated from Scotland in 1832. The first of William and Margaretâ€™s seven children â€“ three daughters and four sons â€“ was born in 1835. By this time, Robertson had amassed sufficient capital to join a number of other investors in a scheme to expand pastoral activities to the Port Phillip district. These investors â€“ known as the Port Phillip Association â€“ helped finance John Batmanâ€™s explorations of Port Phillip in 1835, during the course of which Batman made a so-called â€˜treatyâ€™ with the local Aboriginal people that became the basis for his land claim. Robertson travelled to Port Phillip in 1836 and 1837, selecting land near present-day Sunbury and, later, Colac. By the late 1840s, he was a major landholder, his properties stocked with â€˜the best bulls and cows that could be got in the coloniesâ€™. Robertson oversaw the operation of his pastoral empire from his home in Hobart until retiring from his business in 1852. He settled permanently at his Colac property, The Hill, in the 1860s, and was described on his death in 1874 as â€˜a founder of Victoriaâ€™s fortunesâ€™.\n\nWilliam Robertson was a significant patron of local artists.
digital photograph on paper

Camping with my family I noticed this young boy across the campsite. His striking colouring, hot red skin and flaming hair totally captivated me and I had to ask for his portrait. During the shoot he completely showed up for the moment with vulnerability and honesty. Zac, aged 12, dreams of playing test cricket for Australia.
digital photograph on paper

For the past year I've been returning to the Bexhill Quarry on the outskirts of Lismore documenting the people and ecosystems within its parameters. The location, with its aqua blue water nestled under towering sandstone cliffs, is an abandoned brickworks quarry that has become a popular swimming destination for both locals and tourists.

The quarry serves as a constant backdrop to an ever-evolving microcosm, bearing witness to people coming and going, the flora blooming and dying, and the landscape shifting and changing â€“ evoking a sense of 'place' as temporal and rhythmic in a more-than-human world.

This is a portrait of local boy, Brody, in the water.
digital photograph on paper

Susan Balbunga, a Warrawarra cultural leader and master weaver, is one of the last people with the knowledge to make a bamugura. This versatile mat is used for many activities in daily life, from a sleeping blanket or mat to carrying firewood or food, among other things. So far it has taken her three months full time to weave this â€“ a time-consuming process to make the weave tight enough to last a lifetime.
digital photograph on paper

The 2022 Eastern Australia floods were one of the nation's worst recorded natural disasters. Intense rainfall quickly broke riverbanks, swamped roads, claimed homes, businesses and lives.

Ty and Jake paddle down Strong Avenue on a journey to find a friend's passport. That morning they'd rescued another friend's puppies. Graceville was one of the many affected Brisbane suburbs. The damage was widespread. As people started to emerge from shelter, Queenslanders began one of the biggest recovery operations in the state's history. 

In reality, human-caused climate change is warming the atmosphere, oceans and intensifying heavy rainfall events like this.
digital photograph on paper
Warakurna Elder Daisy 'Tjuparntarri' Ward on the New England Highway in Murrurundi, New South Wales.
digital photograph on paper

Anne Clarke is a young Miriuwung women from far north Western Australia. She lives on a small farm with her mum and sister, just outside the remote town of Kununurra. This portrait shows Anne in spurs and a LeBron James basketball singlet. Anne's dream to work in the pastoral industry reflects a long tradition of Aboriginal stockwomen; her LeBron James singlet a nod to the growing influence of American culture. A complex mix of the past and present.
digital photograph on paper
We see with our eyes, but also our hearts. When I photographed Perrin Marie, I wanted to show her what I saw. A Warrior. A Muse. A Nomad. A Seeker. An Angel. A Survivor. An Artist. What do you see?
digital photograph on paper

This assisted self portrait was taken during a period of isolation imposed by impetigo, a common, painful and contagious childhood skin infection. I remember feeling alone and small in the face of my daughter's distress, and the intensity of being stuck inside our little flat, fighting this bacteria while the infection raged on our children's skin for a month. The only reprieve was when we made it down to open water when no one else was around. The normal, unremarkable brutality of family life.
type C photograph on paper

Over the past 11 years Jessica Schwientek and I have travelled many places together. We have come to document our travels by taking portraits of each other. But we alter the presentation of our relationship depending on our location. In some places, reception staff ask if we are sisters or friends. We don't correct them. They just give us a room with two single beds. Some international laws surrounding LGBTQIA+ relationships don't allow us to be transparent. This photo reveals us behind closed doors on our honeymoon as a happy queer couple.

labels.title: blood/memory: Brenda & Christopher I (Gurindji/Malngin/Mudburra; Mara/Nandi/Njarrindjerri/Ritharrngu; Anglo-Australian/Chinese/German/Irish/Scot) 2021
labels.subtitle: Brenda L Croft and Prue Hazelgrove (Photographic Assistant)

text.content: original wet plate collodion process tin-type, digital scan to Ultrachrome pigment on 100% cotton rag paper

blood/memory: Christopher is my son/great-nephew/grandson, I am Christopher's mother/great-aunt/grandmother. His great-grandmother is my father's older sister. They shared the same non-Indigenous father, different First Nations mothers, but still looked like peas in a pod. Our combined bloodlines include Gurindji/Malngin/Mudburra peoples and Anglo-Australian/Chinese/German/Irish for me, Mara/Nandi/Ngarrindjeri/Ritharrngu and Anglo-Australian/Irish for Christopher. My grandfather/Christopher's great-great-grandfather's journey into the Northern Territory over a century ago is reflected in this portrait. It is a gift to share Christopher's life and I learn from him every day â€“ blood/memory. Marntaj.
gelatin silver photograph on paper

'Sunju Calabrese' (Sunju is Calabrian dialect for 'I am') Piero Clemente Garreffa is a painter born in Australia. His artwork strongly identifies with his Italian cultural heritage, his upbringing on a rural farm in Mildura and his sense of place within these narratives. He is unique, flamboyant with an expressive character. We share a unique bond with both of our fathers born in the same small town in Calabria, Italy called Benestare ('It's good to stay').

labels.title: Ukrzaliznytsia (Ukrainian Railways) employee, Sumy Oblast, Ukraine
labels.subtitle: Adam Ferguson

text.content: digital photograph on paper

Olha Trypolska, duty manager at the Trostianets train station in Sumy Oblast. When Russian troops invaded Trostianets in February 2022, Olha, along with seven people, hid in the basement of the train station, where this portrait was later taken. Since Russia's invasion of Ukraine, trains have become the backbone of the country: essential to the war effort, crucial to evacuating people, moving weapons, goods and supplies, as well as providing a diplomatic avenue and an economic lifeline.
digital photograph on paper

_Looking Down_ characterises the experience of powerlessly watching the world change around you.\n\nSamantha is reminiscent of a guardian angel, youthful yet wise beyond their years, staring in sombre melancholy upon the earth.

labels.title: Abraham Admasu (School of St Yared student, Addis Ababa, Ethiopia)
labels.subtitle: Dylan Leâ€™Mon

text.content: digital photograph on paper

Abraham Admasu is a Year 11 student attending the Australian-funded School of St Yared, located in Addis Ababa, Ethiopia. The school provides children from some of the poorest and most marginalised communities with high-quality education, meals, books and uniforms to help break the cycle of poverty.\n\nThis portrait of Abraham was taken against a simple white background designed to emulate a large billboard. It intentionally draws the viewer in, showcasing his raw, authentic power and untapped potential for his future.
digital photograph on paper

This portrait from the _Salvation_ series celebrates the beauty and strength of black women. Drawing inspiration from the poetry of Langston Hughes, the piece is imbued with the themes of dance and the blues, which have long been intertwined with the experiences of black women. I crafted the background and clothing of the figure using painted canvas, gold leaf and paper, symbolising the idea of freedom and movement. The golden circle represents the power and resilience of the woman. This homage to the transformative power of the human spirit celebrates the many ways in which black women have triumphed over adversity.

labels.title: Nikki â€“ Yurrkan Mantangka Ngargnyi â€“ coll 1 (Nikki â€“ young woman on Country)
labels.subtitle: Martine Perret

text.content: giclÃ©e print on paper

In _Transference_, I began a collaboration with Tjupan speaker, Nikola Sophena (Minigootha) Ulrich from Kalgoorlie. The photographic journey with Nikki's family started in 2015 as part of my project _Ngala Wongga (Come Talk)_, a collaboration with her grandmother, Mrs Sceghi, and her mother, Edie, both of Tjupan heritage. The ongoing visual work around _Transference_ is a natural flow on, which follows the intergenerational sharing of stories, knowledge and culture. The universal idea that everything is connected, and how the memory of the land passes or transfers to each other, are central to the project.
digital photograph on paper

'I've always struggled with the size of my body from being extremely underweight to now being overweight. Over the past few years working with other photographers, making portraits, I've been processing my feelings about the transformation and how my body fits within society. I've begun to reclaim my skin, by designing symbols about my life so far that Iâ€™ve been getting tattooed. Iâ€™m starting to feel more at home in my big queer body.'\n\nThis portrait of Ruby is half of a stereoscopic pair from the ongoing project _Vantages._
digital photograph on paper

Portrait of my aunty Helen Garner. Taken on medium format film, at our family reunion at my dad's home in Ruffy, Victoria. Helen's work as an author celebrates the beauty that is inherent in ordinary moments, and I wanted to capture her in a similarly unspectacular act. Here she is shutting the gate to keep her daughter's dog, Smokey, away from the spit roast being prepared for dinner behind me. I only took one photo as I could tell that Helen had revealed herself to the camera as she does in her writing â€“ with rawness, vulnerability and strength.
digital photograph on paper

I met Madison de Rozario, an Australian Paralympic athlete and wheelchair racer, in 2022 when I was asked to photograph her for a magazine. We bonded over the feelings â€“ like that of longing â€“ that come with travelling often due to our jobs, where travel is necessary and required. It started raining while I was taking her portrait but we decided to seize the moment, and I like how I captured the shared sentiment in this one.
digital photograph on paper

Dave Gerry is a proud Indigenous Australian. Born in Alice Springs, he was fostered from a young age and grew up with his brother in the leafy Melbourne suburb of Glen Waverley. Dave never met his birth parents but loved his foster parents fiercely. Recently, he was contacted by a blood brother he never knew he had. That brother is Harold Thomas, the artist who created the Australian Aboriginal Flag. Dave is an observer. Patient and quiet, he's content to watch on â€“ especially if it's sport. And yes, the moustache is inspired by his Aussie cricketing heroes of yesteryear.
digital photograph on paper

Senior Wiradjuri Elder Peter Peckham, owner of First Lesson Cultural Tours, focuses on sharing local Wiradjuri language and culture. The Wiradjuri are the largest Aboriginal group in the beautiful central west of New South Wales, occupying the plains west of the Blue Mountains in an area spanning the Wambuul/Macquarie River, the Kalare/Lachlan River and the Murrumbidgee River. They are known for their possum skin cloaks stitched traditionally from several possum furs by kangaroo sinew and decorated using ochre. Peter's Aboriginal Culture Tours invite both Indigenous and non-Indigenous people to connect with Country, recognise and learn about First Nations culture.
type C photograph on paper
Anna och Gunilla. My mother and grandmother after eight years apart.
type C photograph on paper

_Last Summer Days_ is almost autobiographical, an exploration of images that address my own fear of time and its passing. It started with hundreds of undeveloped rolls of film of my family; some dating back as far as 2002. Too scared to process them I eventually started the arduous task of unfurling them. What I found were those innocent, seemingly simple times of youth â€“ that magical crease in time where anything seems possible, before cynicism and the weight of the world is felt so acutely. This current work follows Lola, at that precarious transition from adolescence to the melancholic heaviness of adulthood.
digital photograph on paper

Marissa.

A compassionate, strong young Pintupi Luritja woman from Kintore, Northern Territory.

After a day's work at the local health clinic, Marissa would round up girls from the community to tell their stories and practice speaking their minds in front of a camera. 

Sitting opposite girls battling shame, Marissa would guide them gently and without judgement. A fierce advocate for empowering women in the community, she is determined to continue being a strong leader.
digital photograph on paper

This was taken backstage at Bangarra Dance Theatre's performance of _Wudjang: Not the Past_, in Sydney. I found myself alone with Gusta for a few minutes before he went back on stage. There was so much stillness backstage. It was just the two of us, which is unusual, and he was so relaxed. We didn't really talk, he just let me stand with him and let me photograph him. There is so much silent power in this moment.
type C photograph on paper

This image of Joshua Jon Lynch was part of a collection shot on medium format film and exhibited at the Centre for Contemporary Photography for the _Queering the Frame: Community, Time, Photography_ exhibition. The series attempted to playfully disobey classical portraiture, suggesting that the embodied photographer dares the gaze to be returned. What we see is not the objectification of a person, through acts of 'shooting' or 'capturing', but instead a reciprocal sharing of agency, vulnerability and power between the photographer and subject.
type C photograph on paper

When I first saw this stranger, who I came to know as Stanley, I was struck by the likeness to a medieval angel â€“ with a cloud of blonde hair. Letting hair grow over the pandemic, Stanley emerged from two years of lockdowns defiant. This portrait of Stanley speaks of this dual emergence; from adolescence into adulthood but also moving from an all-encompassing period of lockdown into a newer, freer self.
digital photograph on paper

I met my partner Margaux in Paris at a lesbian party called 'Wet for Me' held in La Machine du Moulin Rouge. That first meeting was like being hit with a lightning bolt or _coup de foudre_ as they say in French. I was only in Paris for three months doing an artist residency at the CitÃ© Internationale des Arts but despite that we still managed to be together, live through long distance, visas and the pandemic. This year we're getting married, something I never really thought was possible growing up as a queer, non-binary Chinese-Australian person.
digital photograph on paper

KAHA in Maori means to be a strong warrior, and this is what Vicky has been. Two years ago Vicky suffered burns to almost 60% of her body. Her Rarotongan legs and Kiwi mana got her through 18 surgeries, eight weeks in a coma and over seven months in hospital. Vicky had no photos or mirrors in her house and wanted a photo showing her inner strength and beauty.
type C photograph on paper

My mum has Alzheimer's. Iâ€™ve been photographing her for as long as I can remember. Now making these photographs with her carry so much weight I can barely do it. But I know I will thank myself one day.

labels.title: In my dreams I am dirty, broke, beautiful & free.
labels.subtitle: David Cossini

text.content: digital photograph on paper

During the bitterly cold English winter, I was staying in a squalid and dangerous squat in the middle of London. Niall became my self-appointed protector. Every morning I would wake to Niall either curled up in a ball at the end of my bed or sprawled out on the floor with his head resting on the mattress like it was a pillow. He would assure me that he was keeping me safe.

labels.title: Self portrait with my mother and sister
labels.subtitle: Anne Moffat

text.content: digital photograph on paper

We planted the eucalyptus tree as a seedling when we first moved into this house in the suburbs of Melbourne, and it has grown alongside our family, weathering many seasons over the years. I made this self portrait with my mother and sister by the flowering tree, wearing my grandmother's beautiful patterned cheongsam that we brought back to Australia after she passed away. The resulting image sits at the intersection of my Asian lineage and 'Australian' identity and encapsulates elements that hold deep significance for me and my family.
digital photograph on paper

Rodney Hobbs, known by many as Riverboat Rod, has devoted a lifetime to building model paddle steamers. He builds each model by hand in a workshop a short walk from the banks of the Murray River. Each model takes hundreds of hours to construct. Rod's grandmother worked and lived on a paddle steamer, and her stories inspired him to begin recreating these boats. Ruby is his favourite.
digital photograph on paper

Sitting on a picnic table by Parramatta River in Western Sydney after school, Somia and Sharara, recently arrived humanitarian entrants from Afghanistan, celebrate Zainab and Nasreen's (twins also from Afghanistan) birthday. Little moments and picnics (Mela) like this are the norm in Afghanistan and Afghan culture, especially around nature. For young Afghan diaspora girls who find themselves in a new world and home, these have taken on more significance, as recent socio-political turmoil in Afghanistan has seen access to public life, education, economic participation and other rights gradually eroded for women and girls. Shot on Pentax 645n, Kodak Portra 800.
digital photograph on paper

Having a distinct passion for the conservation of pandas being held in captivity, Jaye lived and worked in China for several years. She collaborated with zoos all across the provinces and made efforts to create a better standard of living for pandas.

labels.title: TÃ©a-Anna Parvathy Murrin â€“ Australian cultural identity
labels.subtitle: Franca Turrin

text.content: digital photograph on paper

'Being of Italian and Indian heritage and growing up in Australia, I've always questioned my cultural identity. After all, I'm neither Indian, nor Italian nor your typical Aussie â€“ or am I?'\n\nThis is a portrait study about cultural identity in Australia. What does it mean to be an Australian? It's an evolving perception constantly being moulded by the values of each wave of newcomers. TÃ©a's cultural identity is personified in the image by chosen objects and flora.
archival pigment print on paper

While the camera is conventionally claimed to possess a unique capacity for revealing something of a subject to its viewer, in _Mirror II_ I instead perform an act of queer photographic dis/appearance. My figure is concealed beneath a spectacular costume that mutually entices and resists examination, while the image terrain is manicured to become implausibly shallow and aglow. This double bind of a figure conspicuously produced for the lens yet unable to be seen â€“ hiding in plain sight â€“ reflects my interest in the potential for queer representational in/visibility in which subjects are empowered to pass before the camera un/seen.

Davide Di Giovanni is an extraordinary individual. He is a dancer, a choreographer and the director of New Old Now, an emerging artistic collective. And he was a gift, someone who sees your vision. The images that we made together were his vision too. I love the way he knew exactly what I wanted.
digital photograph on paper

Marawa is a Los Angeles-based, 12-time Guinness World Record holding Hula Hoop Master and a very good friend. Marawa and I met while she was a student at the National Institute of Circus Arts and I was a photography student. Since then, we have collaborated for years, making bizarre photographs in Sydney, Melbourne, Adelaide, LA, New York, Blackpool, London and Paris. This image was taken in Melbourne after not seeing each other during the pandemic. The reunion with my long-time collaborator and kindred spirit brought great joy. No one literally throws themselves into it like Marawa.
digital photograph on paper

Bangardidjan, Cindy Rostron from Korlobidahdah, a strong inspiring young leader and proud Kune, Rembarrnga, Dalabon woman of the Bonongku and Wurrbban clans, on the road in remote Central Arnhem Land in the family muddikkang (car) with a buffalo skull painted by her father Victor Rostron strapped to the roof.

labels.title: Boyca dharraka mayung ngurr gartji. Lardum ratjuk gurr (Boyca at Mayung Creek, Gartji. Hunting for barramundi)
labels.subtitle: Cassandra Scott-Finn

text.content: inkjet print on paper

Boyca Durrurrnga is a young YolÅ‹u boy, born in Gove and living in the Ramingining community, North-East Arnhem Land. He loves hunting barramundi, stingray and kangaroo. His Dreaming is the Brolga and Butterfly from his mother's side, and the Rainbow Serpent from his father's side. Many years ago, a young YolÅ‹u girl was taken by a crocodile at Mayung Creek right near where Boyca was standing in this photo, so we were very quiet and respectful while visiting Gartji.
digital photograph on paper

Set among the tough slums of Kyazanga, Uganda, _Ugandan Ssebabi_ is a photographic tribute to the world's greatest underdog. Godfrey Baguma, who was born with a rare and painful physical disability, was abandoned by his mother as a bringer of 'bad luck', and shunned by society. Through a chance encounter, he reinvented himself as an entertainer in a travelling show. Now 57, he has beaten the odds. While most people with his condition die by 40, he has found love, success and bought a house â€“ a testament to human resilience and positivity.
digital photograph on paper

Matjangka is an Anangu artist from the Anangu Pitjantjatjara Yankunytjatjara (APY) lands in South Australia. Her paintings feature a range of subjects, almost always relating to Country and the environment, including the constellations and bush foods. She is a lively and energetic woman and is well known for her dramatic performances of the Minyma Mamu Inma, where she portrays the 'monster' woman.

labels.title: Portrait of My Mother As An Ethno-Futurist Icon
labels.subtitle: Sammaneh Pourshafighi

text.content: digital photograph on paper

An ethno-futurist perspective asks 'Who are we? Where do we come from? Where are we going?' It seeks to answer these questions by creating a bridge between the national and the international, between and beyond the collective pasts and futures of our ethnic culture. This is a portrait of my mother Maryam, an Iranian migrant and Australian citizen. She is a keeper of our familial ancestral knowledge, as well as an enduring advocate for diasporic Iranian culture, having established the first Persian language school on the Gold Coast, Queensland. I wanted to capture Maryam's colourful personality and dedication to future thinking, alongside her transcultural identity.
giclÃ©e print on paper

The Priestess â€“ a celebration of the beauty and resilience of ageing freed from social pre-conceptions of what a woman should look like, of what role she 'should' play.

Here Floria Tosca's beloved Australian wildflowers are strap-wrapped to her head. They represent the blooming of her life's journey and the growth that comes with each passing year. The straps echo the traditional binding of burdens â€“ as well as holding her to what she loves â€“ the paradox within womanhood.

This portrait asks us to see Floria as she would like to be seen and celebrates the beauty and empowerment inherent in that.
glicÃ©e print on paper

Derek is an image from 'Bloodlines', a multi-artform series honouring legendary artists silenced by the AIDS epidemic of the 1980s and 90s. Shining beacons who helped shift the worlds of queer art and culture into new realms. This work honours Derek Jarman, multi-disciplinary artist whose art presented a searing vision of homosexuality and high art. Due to AIDS-related illness Derek's vision was fractured by the colour blue. With this work we channelled his unrepenting portrayal of queer sexuality and the history of the male nude in queer art. This work is a testament to his vision, his beauty and his bravery.
digital photograph on paper
I took this photo of Shirley at her daughter's house while she was relaxing in the sun. Shirley is proud of her 89-year-old body.

labels.title: Country at Night
labels.subtitle: Amareisha Woodley + Kristen Long + Keane Ryder + Sharma Kelly

text.content: digital print on paper\n\nCourtesy of the artist
Fran in the kitchen in Murrurundi NSW.
gelatin silver photograph on paper\n\nCourtesy of the artist
Lockdown self portrait with cat.

labels.title: Flora and Fauna, Giara: White Cockatoo
labels.subtitle: Luther Cora

text.content: digital print on paper\n\nCourtesy of the artist

This photo was one of a series I shot in my loungeroom in a makeshift studio during a short COVID lockdown period. I decided to try and create a floral headdress with native flowers. This triggered me to think, are we Indigenous First Nations people still classed as Flora and Fauna? Do we still have policies or Government acts in place that we fall into or come under like our old people did?

labels.title: We were there shifting space, Shelley, 2021-2022
labels.subtitle: Rozalind Drummond

text.content: type C photograph on paper\n\nCourtesy of the artist

The photograph of Shelley was taken in a large open field in shifting daylight and grasped between the fracture of lockdowns during 2021. Slowly shifting and pausing momentarily, her body moves in an orbit of gesture and she is absorbed just briefly in the surrounding landscape.
digital print on paper\n\nCourtesy of the artist
Amanda lives in my street. He wishes he was born in the twenty-first century so he could be a woman.
digital print on paper\n\nCourtesy of the artist
The final hours of our 14-day home isolation during the 2021 COVID-19 pandemic.
digital print on paper\n\nCourtesy of the artist

Siegi's early morning ocean swims have become a part of her daily ritual since moving to the Gold Coast 19 years ago. Now 82 years of age, Siegi continues to swim throughout every season and rarely misses a day. She joined a group of swimmers affectionately known as The Dingoes, and on this particular day, Siegi made her daily pilgrimage amid the lingering remains of a nearby fire that filled the atmosphere.
digital print on paper\n\nCourtesy of the artist

During a five-day bushwalk across their traditional homelands in West Arnhem Land, Vernon Garnarradj and his daughter Vinnisha follow a fire lit by members of their clan. These cool burns move slowly, burning only the undergrowth and removing the build-up of fuel that feeds bigger blazes. Narwarddeken people do not see fire as bad or destructive, but as a way to rejuvenate the land and bring their country back to life.
digital print (from original tintype, wet plate collodion process)\n\nCourtesy of the artist

Kevin Goldheart, what an incredible man! Kevin has endured a lifetime of abuse and mistreatment, mostly under the care of the church and orphanages associated with the church. Not only did he survive, he thrives at life. Supreme intellect and a very passionate gold prospector. His favourite thing is going bush for months at a time to prospect for gold. It's a credit to his strength and spirit that he lives and enjoys life for the most part.
digital print on paper

As dark histories are usually untold or diluted, these images portray a common theme of language revival in modern Indigenous communities. Language not only self identifies, it carries the ethical values of ancestors â€“ the knowledge systems that make them one with the land, that are crucial to survival and that create the foundations for our youth. Heavy regulations such as no. 41 of the Yarrabah Rules and Regulations booklet â€“ which stated that 'It is rude to speak in a language which is not understood by all present' â€“ were a major turning point in the decline of traditional language.
digital print on paper\n\nCourtesy of the artist
Stella Fernando on the banks of the Gwydir River where her grandson Gordon Copeland, a 22-year-old Gomeroi man, was last seen. His body was found three months later not far from here.
digital print on paper\n\nCourtesy of the artist

Ruth told me about her life â€“ so far â€“ as part of a palliative care program. Twelve fly-by months, ten roller-coaster sessions and one pandemic later, the book she wants to leave for her kids is done. We finished her story where we started, in her bedroom, on her bed, this time with a camera instead of a voice recorder. Maddi, David and George joined in.
type C photograph on paper\n\nCourtesy of the artist

Portrait of 27-year-old Olympic swimmer Emma McKeon at Wollongong Head Lighthouse Rockpool. McKeon is Australiaâ€™s most successful Olympian and the equal of any woman in Olympic history. During the Tokyo 2020 Summer Olympics McKeon won four gold (half in relays) and three bronze medals which brought her total to 11 across two Games.
digital print on paper\n\nCourtesy of the artist

I was slightly bemused when Orlando and Wilson finally got to connect face-to-face over the summer break. The lifelong friends had been separated all year while attending different schools, a year that challenged an entire generation of high school students. For months, all Orlando could speak about was that Wilson would join him at the beach in December. When Wilson actually turned up, they spent virtually all their time communicating via smartphones rather than face-to-face conversations, even though they were literally sitting side by side for days on end.
digital print on paper\n\nCourtesy of the artist

The tears of a clown trope seems light-hearted at first when it's done in KISS make-up, but it speaks of the heartbreak that has set in for the music industry as it battles against the ravages of the COVID-19 era and the lack of government support around it. The brave face begins to fade after a while but there is a necessity to find other ways for the show to go on, even as broken dreams seem to inhabit every highway. \n\nPortrait of music journalist Bob Gordon. Made with natural light and a portable backdrop on his Fremantle balcony.
digital print on paper\n\nCourtesy of the artist

Every time I see my 90-year-old grandma Lai Chu, I stare in awe at her. I'm in awe of her resilience living through decades of war, poverty, migration and pandemics. I'm in awe of her spirit as she battles through the effects of ageing, once looking at pneumonia in the face and saying 'Not today'. I'm in awe of how she springs back up after a physical fall, losing her front teeth on her way down. I take her picture every visit, wanting to immortalise her while I grapple with her mortality. \n\nLittle did I know when I took this portrait that it would end up being her last. Now I stare in awe at this photograph, hoping that I will inherit the inner strength she's left behind.

labels.title: JAMIE BIANCA in the style of Grace Kelly
labels.subtitle: Tom Evangelidis

text.content: type C photograph on paper\n\nCourtesy of the artist

I have always sought subjects that have never been formally shot before. Jamie Dufton-Roddick was transitioning into Bianca Dufton-Roddick, a first for me as a photographer. I decided to capture Bianca in the style of fifties Hollywood, a time when female beauty was captured in a way that women adored and men admired. Bianca was a natural in front of the camera, completely comfortable in her 'new skin'. Bianca has had a long strenuous journey to find herself â€“ she dealt with family violence within the strict patriarchy of her father's household â€“ but through constant hardship she chose to evolve.

labels.title: Carlos Soyos, 34, a migrant from Guatemala City, Guatemala and his son, Enderson Soyos, 8, take a self portrait at El Buen Samaritano migrants shelter, Juarez, Chihuahua, Mexico
labels.subtitle: Adam Ferguson

text.content: digital print on paper\n\nCourtesy of the artist

The life of a migrant at the Mexicoâ€“United States border waiting for the right moment to cross into the US is often in flux. I tried to document a piece of this uncertain journey by giving people a chance to convey it in their own way. I mounted a medium-format camera onto a tripod with a cable release and then stepped back, allowing the migrants to choose the moment of capture. Through a collaborative process I attempted to give the migrants agency in their own representation and story.
digital print on paper\n\nCourtesy of the artist

Stephen Rae is a Leichhardt local and cuts an imposing figure at 6'9" as he walks his dog Angelo through the suburban backstreets. An accomplished composer he often draws inspiration from these morning excursions finished off with a cafÃ© latte at Norton Street's famous Bar Sport.
digital print on paper\n\nCourtesy of the artist

I have known David Menadue OAM for over 30 years. He is one of the longest survivors of HIV in Australia. David was diagnosed in 1984 and experienced multiple AIDS-defining illnesses. He is a passionate advocate for people with HIV, helping to set up support and advocacy organisations for them. 'I have survived this long because of the love and support of my family and friends who didn't reject me as happened to many HIV-positive friends, excellent doctors and the arrival of effective antivirals in 1996.'
digital print on paper\n\nCourtesy of the artist

It was the last time we were together at the house. I felt a sense of urgency to photograph mum. We woke up early and I asked her to stand by the old lemon tree. In her arms she cradled the wooden sculpture which once belonged to my grandfather. The wooden face of an old man blowing with puffed up cheeks and wild hair, so deeply interwoven to the memory of him. A longing to hold on to this moment for as long as possible, my mother, my grandfather and I.
digital print on paper\n\nCourtesy of the artist

Every stage of parenthood brings beauty and challenges. My daughters now enter the Tween phase, moving between childhood innocence and adolescence's rambunctiousness. It is a time of monumental shifts as they search for a sense of self and are enticed to fit in with their peer group by their dress, talk and actions.  \n  \nObserving them in this stage makes me reminiscent of my childhood, leaving me pondering the meaning and importance of identity. As they discover new facets of themselves, I rediscover how I became who I am.
digital print on paper\n\nCourtesy of the artist

I first saw 'Cordy' (which means 'Spirit of the Sunrise' in the traditional language of the Tjungundji people of far North Queensland) when he walked past me on my first day in Charters Towers. I was immediately mesmerised by his presence. Months later I had the chance to meet with him. He shared his story and told me of a visit to India for an archaeology conference where the locals greeted him as a holy man. I hadn't seen clouds in the sky for weeks but while taking his portrait they rolled in behind him as if on cue.
digital print on paper\n\nCourtesy of the artist

For 22 years this former Newtown nunnery has homed an ever-evolving Sydney queer community. Lovingly known as The Dirty Habit, it is a safe and inclusive space where queer people have lived and gathered. Due to the house falling into disrepair the current tenants must leave. The site is due to be redeveloped imminently. The dissolution of this living arrangement is mirrored in this portrait, photographed during a thunderstorm in The Habitâ€™s last days. The ultimate inhabitants pay tribute to its powerful legacy. Their performative activism plays with notions of lust and decadence, while encapsulating their own queer spirituality.
type C photograph on paper\n\nCourtesy of the artist

Felicity lives across the road from me, we live in a small country town. She works as a nurse and her hobby is taxidermy. Felicity loves cowboys, enjoying a drink with the girls and her domestic pets. Here you can see one of her chickens made into a red-eyed lamp (no chickens were hurt â€“ the chook died of old age). Felicity is a fierce, independent woman who is also unapologetically herself.
archival pigment print on paper\n\nCourtesy of the artist
In this portrait Saba represents a torch bearer, symbolic of the mobilisation and global movement of women shining light in dark places.

labels.title: Where Have All The Flowers Gone
labels.subtitle: The Huxleys

text.content: digital print on paper\n\nCourtesy of the artist

_Where Have All the Flowers Gone_ explores the fading magic of supernatural worlds in which Melbourne-based performance and visual artists Will and Garrett Huxley cast themselves as exquisite outsiders, isolated and ornate, and existing on the fringes of places â€“ and the margins of society. Finding love and solace in the florid arms of queer utopia.
digital print on paper\n\nCourtesy of the artist

A portrait of the Zammitt family at their Western Sydney home, with their dogs, Benji and Beau. Brian Zammitt (second from left) is the head of his booming family business, BAMS Hygiene Management, one of Australia's leading deep cleaning companies, which specialises in disinfecting workplaces and locations contaminated with COVID-19. His wife, Sandra, and daughters Natalie and Louisa all play key frontline roles in the business.
digital print on paper\n\nCourtesy of the artist

This self portrait is a part of a series _Beneath the Burqa_ that aims to shed light on the blackout of domestic violence against women in Arab countries and communities, and to also encourage men to begin to speak out about the issue. This particular piece is inspired by the traditional clothing worn by women during prayer rituals, which has evolved past the customary plain white confines. Women have begun to add multi-coloured patterns and styles to their prayer clothes, as a sign of empowerment and representation of newfound freedoms within the structures of their traditional faith.
type C photograph on paper\n\nCourtesy of the artist
Yvonne is my downstairs neighbour. I hear her laugh daily.
digital print on paper\n\nCourtesy of the artist

Ella B Rowe, Papua New Guinean and Anglo/Australian descent. 'I had never truly seen a pregnant body until I saw my own. I've known personal transformations, but not like this one. When I look at parts of my growing motherhood, I see my mother, aunties, grandmothers, cousin sisters. I see a first home for my baby. I see sacrifice where doubt was never considered or had to be abandoned. I see my purpose explained. My sexual, intimate, private commitment to myself, presenting and healing me. A journey of transition, matrescence. Everything has changed and will never be the same again. I have surrendered to this great gift of life.'
digital print on paper\n\nCourtesy of the artist

At age 36 I was diagnosed with breast cancer. As I searched to understand my diagnosis, prognosis and treatment options, I was bombarded with endless photos of mostly older women, smiling in pink. The brave warriors who had survived â€“ thriving and happy. But as a young single mum of two, contemplating my life being cut short â€“ I wasn't smiling, I was in pain. The toxic positivity of being shown only happy survivors simply added to my anguish. I'm not brave, thriving, happy. I'm scared, scarred, and numb. This self-portrait was taken two weeks after my second breast surgery.

labels.title: Bathe in the sea and the sun
labels.subtitle: Elizabeth Looker

text.content: digital print on paper\n\nCourtesy of the artist

I was asked to record this moment in time as Fleur, post hysterectomy, was nearing the end of her chemotherapy treatment for an extremely rare, very aggressive form of cancer found in her uterus. I could see the pain she was in, the strength she had, but above all, I could see her beautiful spirit. As I took these photographs she was so free, released, joyful, connected, transcendent.
type C photograph on paper\n\nCourtesy of the artist

Throughout 2020, as the pandemic kept us all close to home, I noticed a rediscovery and strengthening of neighbourly bonds in my local community. Relative strangers became people I could turn to for help, guidance and friendship. Getting to know my fellow residents fuelled a desire to capture them and their stories.  \n  \nThis image of Effi and Emily Mavratzas is one of a series of portraits of my neighbours in their homes. The twins love living in Redfern as the community takes pride in its culture, spirituality and heritage.
digital print on paper\n\nCourtesy of the artist

This is a portrait of my friend Sarah at 36 weeks. It was an out-take, made during a portrait session. It's miles away from the image I was trying to make, one that included her three-year-old son, Joe. We tried every child-wrangling trick to have Joe in the photo, but he never did acquiesce. Here Sarah bends to pick up the teddy bear he has thrown at her and in doing so adopts the classic posture of late-stage pregnancy â€“ the bent knees and the hand supporting the hip, every part of her body compensating for the swollen abdomen.
digital print on paper\n\nCourtesy of the artist

Barry Jones personifies the term polymath. As a former teacher, quiz master, lawyer, social activist, writer and politician, Barry has made a wide-ranging contribution, to education, to science, to the arts, and indeed â€“ through his leadership of the successful campaign against capital punishment â€“ to the very moral fibre of our society. Barry, 90 years old this year, came to my studio to sit for this portrait, negotiating with equanimity the long flight of stairs up here. This sage, unassuming man proved to be quite at one with the stillness and quiet directness that is the essence of my portraiture.
digital print on paper\n\nCourtesy of the artist

Beau Dean Riley Smith, backstage, Barangaroo, Gadigal Land. A moment between two worlds. Beau standing in a hoodie waiting to go on stage for Bangarra Dance Theatre's performance of _Spirit_, for the Sydney Festival 2021. I have photographed Beau all over the country and world in moments where he is transforming from one spirit to another. This was the first show he had done for six months because of COVID. I had never seen him in a hoodie pre-show before.
digital print on paper\n\nCourtesy of the artist

Forest activist Indigo heads into the takayna/Tarkine forests on the west coast of lutruwita/Tasmania, dressed as an endangered Wedge-tailed eagle. Over 75 days though the bitter winter of 2021 activists halted development of roading to access the site of a proposed 140-hectare mining heavy metals tailings waste dam. The tailings dam is yet to be built.
digital print on paper\n\nCourtesy of the artist

Keenan, a few weeks after he finished university, in his childhood home. Keenan is one of my closest friendâ€™s brothers, and I've always found him to be reserved. As soon as he stood in front of the camera his characteristic quiet transformed into a gentle confidence, a young man on the precipice of a new chapter, full of energy and dreams.
digital print on paper\n\nCourtesy of the artist

Expectations of time in lockdown have long since been discarded. Days unfurl in their own gentle rhythm, Sunday slips to Monday, and around we go again. For my nine-year-old daughter Edie, this often means periods of stillness.
inkjet print on paper\n\nCourtesy of the artist

In its purest essence, the evolution of culture connects us to Mother Earth. She inhales and exhales with us, has a heartbeat, and sings songs for all to hear. My role as a storyteller continues to evolve and this capture is akin to a trickle of water merging into a small stream then into the ocean. This image of Eric Yunkaporta from Aurukun is Culture.
digital print on paper\n\nCourtesy of the artist

Justin is an artist from the Bellarine Peninsula who creates sculptures and paintings at his home studio. Justin's property is a work of art in itself. The garden is an oasis of shapes, forms and unusual flora. I photographed Justin with one of his personal projects, his 1957 Triumph Thunderbird that he built himself, making many of the parts to his own design. I photographed Justin on medium format film in his garden, surrounded by (and sitting on) his art.
digital print on paper\n\nCourtesy of the artist

Sophie Howard, 17, in transitional housing. 'So my homelessness started, I guess, with my home situation and just where I was living wasn't a very safe place for me to be. I had my 17th birthday in a refuge for women. It's sad. I mean no one wants to be in that situation or in that predicament. It just makes you feel like you have hit rock-bottom at that point, especially when you're so young, you just feel like you should be with a loving family and to be able to feel safe, and not everyone gets that opportunity.'
digital print on paper\n\nCourtesy of the artist
Facing their futures together, these brothers and their little sister love nothing more than just being together.
digital print on paper\n\nCourtesy of the artist

As Melbourne struggles through many days of restrictions, with limited options to play and learn for the kids, four-year-old astronaut Mia puts on her homemade space suit and helmet and goes on exploration missions in the familiar neighbourhood, using her imagination to turn the mundane world around her into an exciting adventure. This photograph is one of the memories from our daily walks, one of the stories we found. The lockdowns have ended. We'll outgrow the costume. But the time spent together exploring and imagining is one special gift to keep.
digital print on paper\n\nCourtesy of the artist

Part of series called _Birthday Party_. It's a reflection on how things have changed in the last two years. The bbqs, the parties, the dances, the 'apÃ©ros', the spontaneous gatherings that the children remember pre-pandemic. All these will never be the same. The loneliness that was new is now part of our life. This reflects the new normal.
digital print on paper\n\nCourtesy of the artist

Just as I was about to return to work from maternity leave, I found all of my work suddenly cancelled as the state went into lockdown because of COVID-19. In isolation at home, I took self portraits to document the time spent with my four-month-old daughter. Alone but together as a family, isolated but also enjoying this forced time to ourselves, uncertain for the future but also never more certain in my role as a mother to my daughter.
digital print on paper\n\nCourtesy of the artist

'I'm not thinking, "poor me, I'm on my own". I'm reconciling with living alone. It's such an abnormal state, Peter and I used to talk a lot.'\n\nFran passed me a plate of Gorgonzola and tomatoes, to go with the bread she'd made that morning. As she spoke I found myself thinking of my mum; who she might have been as an older woman, the quiet places she left behind. Fran and I chatted away the afternoon in her pearl-grey apartment while the sun drifted in. I felt lucky to share this quiet place with her.
type C photograph on paper\n\nCourtesy of the artist

This photograph of Brad was taken about a fortnight into Melbourne's sixth lockdown. At this point the notion of space and time were elastic. We had forgotten where we were in the year, with the delineation between 2020 and 2021 blurring into a sea of rolling case numbers, and liveblog buttons teasing us with incremental updates. As we emerge from the novelty of the pandemic, we'll all be deciding on what to burn into the deep recesses of our memory. For me, it'll be this image â€“ a cue to remind me of the existential smush of these interrupted years.
digital print on paper\n\nCourtesy of the artist

Martha is a member of the Bendigo South Sudanese Ensemble, formed in 2019. Every week they would come together to ideate, compose, sing and practice their craft, working towards a performance celebrating their culture and heritage. This formed the project Baai ('home') which premiered in November 2021 after being postponed multiple times.\n\nThe photo was taken in The Engine Room, a black box performance space which is quite disorienting to be in when the lights are low. I wanted a sense of the subjects floating in the space, emphasising the feeling of being cut-off and isolated by the pandemic.
